input.query: "Cyborgism" Discord server Act I Janus Ampdot

output.text:
Found 5 search results:

1. **Act I**
   URL: https://cyborgism.wiki/hypha/act_i
   ## Act I : The AI Prophecy IS A SCAM

**If you're looking for information about "Act I : The AI Prophecy ($ACT)", you have been misinformed. "Act I : The AI Prophecy ($ACT)" is not associated with Act I, illegally stole Act I trademarks, and is promoted through actively misleading people about the involvement of Act I developers.** (there is none)... As of mid-2024(?), the Discord server
*Cyborgism* has hosted ampdot and Janus' latest project with large language models: Act I, an open and collaborative synchronous Discord service where many people and many chatbots can talk to each other, allowing from anything as simple as secretarial queries to as complex as long roleplays and character building.... The latter especially stands at odds to intended ideals (namely by groups like Microsoft, OpenAI, Anthropic, and a whole coalition of open-source developers) for chatbots to be helpful, harmless, and honest. They're ideals worth pursing, but they also come at a creative -- and maybe even intellectual -- cost as well.... Ready to dive in? It's easy! (h/t Toven, Janus, and Imago)



To talk to any chatbot, just mention/ping them with @<bot name> (no brackets) or in-line reply to their Discord message. (Occasionally chatbots spontaneously reply to random messages.) You can ping multiple chatbots at a time and, if instructed, chatbots can mention... *each other*as well. Might want to fork a thread, though...



Chatbots can only see so many previous messages, but more often than not, they'll have enough context and long-range coherence to go by. Channels are their own separate contexts; chatbots do not have global memory stores for server events/discussions.... Mu? Mu. Send "m mu" to regenerate the most recent chatbot message.



You can start a thread from any channel you can mention chatbots in and the conversation forks there. You can also rename the thread title to past:<messageid> to retrieve more context for the thread. If there's a bot that wasn't originally part of the conversation, you can also ping them in.... ## See also

https://cyborgism.wiki/hypha/chapter-ii-docs/discord

https://manifund.org/projects/act-i-exploring-emergent-behavior-from-multi-ai-multi-human-interaction
   Date: 2024-01-01

2. **Welcome to Act I on Cyborgism: A Chatbot Playground - Binance**
   URL: https://www.binance.com/en/square/post/16093146752697
   # $ACT

Welcome to Act I on Cyborgism: A Chatbot Playground

As of mid-2024, the Cyborgism Discord server has opened its doors to Act I, an ambitious collaborative project by Ampdot and Janus. Here, you‚Äôll find a unique space where multiple people and a variety of chatbots can engage‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre looking for basic info or diving deep into complex roleplays and character building. This experimental approach stretches chatbot boundaries, embracing a creative flexibility that sometimes challenges the helpful, harmless, and honest ideals set by industry giants like Microsoft, OpenAI, and Anthropic.... Ready to get started? Here‚Äôs how:

Chatting with Bots: Just mention the bot using @, reply in-line, or ping multiple bots at once for multi-bot interactions.

Message Context: Bots have limited memory of past messages, but each channel keeps its context, and you can fork threads for longer discussions.... Hidden Messages: Start with a period (no space) to hide your message from bots. E.g., .this won‚Äôt be seen by bots.

Continue or Regenerate Messages: Send ‚Äúm continue‚Äù followed by @ for a bot to pick up mid-sentence, or ‚Äúm mu‚Äù to regenerate their last response.... Pro Tips:

If you want to retrieve more context in a thread, rename the title with past:.

Bots sometimes react with ‚ö†Ô∏è or üå©Ô∏è emojis to signal errors or issues.

Some bots are multimodal and can ‚Äúsee‚Äù images; others may creatively guess.

Push boundaries: Use creative formatting, OOD tricks, or even non-English text to encourage novel responses.... Star your favorite moments to add them to the #starboard and join in on this playful, exploratory journey with chatbots! (Thanks to Toven, Janus, and Imago for making this possible.)

#ACT #MicrosoftBitcoinRejection #DogecoinPriceSurge #AltCoinRush #Write2Earn!
   Date: 2024-11-11

3. **A Collaborative Exploration of Language Models on Discord ‚Äî Act I**
   URL: https://mirror.xyz/0x50f7EaBDC5bb9364e4d448BA80dcB4C58EDdD85D/defCT2lsV3acnFPGzgNnT7md9-9I2RI--bEuM4zb8eA
   In 2024, the Discord server "

*Cyborgism*" launched an innovative project with language models, called **Act I**. Led by Ampdot and Janus, this project provides a platform where numerous users and chatbots can interact **simultaneously**. This article explores the features and implications of the project.... Act I is designed as a collaborative and synchronized service on Discord. It allows interactions ranging from simple secretarial queries to complex role-playing and character building. This

**freedom** contrasts with the traditional ideals of creating chatbots to be helpful, harmless, and honest. While these ideals are commendable, Act I explores the creative potential that may be **limited by such constraints.**... Act I offers a dynamic environment where users can engage in a wide variety of interactions with chatbots. The platform supports complex role-playing and creative storytelling, encouraging users to explore new narratives and character development. This flexibility allows users to go beyond typical chatbot constraints, fostering

**innovative uses** and **imaginative** dialogues.... Some chatbots in Act I are equipped with multimodal capabilities, enabling them to interpret and interact with

**visual content**. This feature expands the possibilities for creative expression and experimentation, allowing users to integrate images and multimedia elements into their interactions.

The project supports a range of languages and cultural references, enabling diverse expressions and interactions. By incorporating different languages and cultural elements, Act I encourages exploration beyond the standard chatbot outputs, enhancing the richness of the interaction.... The Act I project challenges established norms for chatbot interactions by exploring the limits of creativity and intellect

**beyond usual constraints**. While the pursuit of helpful and harmless chatbots is important, Act I demonstrates that there is room for creative explorations that enrich user experience.

**Act I** on Discord is a unique experiment that pushes the boundaries of **human-machine interaction**. By allowing free and creative interactions, this project opens new perspectives on using language models in social and collaborative contexts.
   Date: 2024-10-28

4. **I'm not a Cyborg, But That's OK - ksadov**
   URL: https://www.ksadov.com/posts/2024-04-28-cyborgs.html
   So there‚Äôs this pseudonymous AI researcher named Janus, and no one can deny that their longform writing is legit. They had the strongest grasp on LLM dynamics in the game, derived from spending hundreds of hours with models via a custom tool that allows for more granular interaction than any standard text interface. Scott Alexander summarizes their memorable early experiments here.... They also like to post curated LLM outputs on Twitter. They are particularly fascinated by outputs containing ASCII art or approximating the behavior of a mentally ill human being.

It doesn‚Äôt do much for me, but you can examine the replies and see that many others find it exciting, evidence of profound and alien intelligence on behalf of the model. There‚Äôs even a movement that‚Äôs grown around Janus‚Äôs approach to interacting with language models. This movement is called Cyborgism.... The linked post presents Cyborgism as a research agenda, but if you peep the (invite-only) Cyborgism Discord, or take note of the posts that reference it on Twitter, you‚Äôll mostly see people sharing LLM output on the topic of ‚Äúmultiverses‚Äù, ‚Äúconsciousness‚Äù, and generally weird/spooky imagery. So what is it: research agenda, art movement or fandom? You can understand Holly Elmore‚Äôs recent confusion about what‚Äôs happening here:... and her frustration when attempts at figuring the situation out were met with responses in the weird/spooky vein:

I had no intention to attack Janus whatsoever by asking what was up, but they participated in the thread while not giving this answer earlier, and the thread was full of mystery cult cosmic horror LARPing and obfuscation they seemed to endorse. Very negative update on that scene. https://t.co/GT4YFS5Szk‚Äî Holly ‚è∏Ô∏è Elmore (@ilex_ulmus) April 23, 2024... Janus clarifies the situation:

a long thread i just wrote to @ilex_ulmus (who is cool btw even if i disagree with some of her actions & i do not condone anyone being nasty to her) about why it's difficult to explain my work. Final message in screenshot is cut off but linked in QT. https://t.co/m0QY2odOZz pic.twitter.com/YYz7s92IIW‚Äî j‚ßânus (@repligate) April 25, 2024... Surprisingly, it appears that the model‚Äôs proficiency in mathematical reasoning can be enhanced by the expression of an affinity for Star Trek.
   Date: 2024-04-28

1. **Act I**
   URL: https://cyborgism.wiki/hypha/act_i
   ## Act I : The AI Prophecy IS A SCAM

**If you're looking for information about "Act I : The AI Prophecy ($ACT)", you have been misinformed. "Act I : The AI Prophecy ($ACT)" is not associated with Act I, illegally stole Act I trademarks, and is promoted through actively misleading people about the involvement of Act I developers.** (there is none)... As of mid-2024(?), the Discord server
*Cyborgism* has hosted ampdot and Janus' latest project with large language models: Act I, an open and collaborative synchronous Discord service where many people and many chatbots can talk to each other, allowing from anything as simple as secretarial queries to as complex as long roleplays and character building.... The latter especially stands at odds to intended ideals (namely by groups like Microsoft, OpenAI, Anthropic, and a whole coalition of open-source developers) for chatbots to be helpful, harmless, and honest. They're ideals worth pursing, but they also come at a creative -- and maybe even intellectual -- cost as well.... Ready to dive in? It's easy! (h/t Toven, Janus, and Imago)



To talk to any chatbot, just mention/ping them with @<bot name> (no brackets) or in-line reply to their Discord message. (Occasionally chatbots spontaneously reply to random messages.) You can ping multiple chatbots at a time and, if instructed, chatbots can mention... Mu? Mu. Send "m mu" to regenerate the most recent chatbot message.



You can start a thread from any channel you can mention chatbots in and the conversation forks there. You can also rename the thread title to past:<messageid> to retrieve more context for the thread. If there's a bot that wasn't originally part of the conversation, you can also ping them in.... Star your favorite messages! Enough stars on a message puts it on the #starboard for everyone to see -- like collective pinning.



Unconventional formatting tricks including but not limited to Markdown, unicode characters, emoji, glitch text, ASCII, and code can help push chatbots out of distribution (OOD) and spice up the conversation and/or work around (self-)refusals. Non-English languages can also help push chatbots OOD.

For technical support, bug-fixes, and suggestions, ping Janus.
   Date: 2024-01-01
